awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Droplet transport in the vicinity of breaking waves: Experiments and simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
The accurate prediction of spray and aerosol generation at the ocean surface is essential for a wide variety of applications including weather and climate predictions. This research aims at characterizing and quantifying droplet transport in the turbulent airflow around breaking surface waves in the ocean. A unique combined experimental and numerical approach is designed. At the air-sea interaction laboratory at the University of Delaware, controlled, repeatable breaking wave events will be re-produced, and measurements of droplet concentration and velocity for different droplet sizes will be used to directly estimate production fluxes. At the University of Notre Dame, measured waveforms and droplet production rates are used as inputs into large eddy simulations configured to recreate laboratory conditions. Droplet statistics are directly compared between experiments and simulations, and the simulations will provide a means for investigating momentum and thermodynamic exchange rates, as well as upscaling to field conditions. Numerical weather and climate models require accurate parameterizations of marine aerosol source fluxes, and only by understanding droplet transport immediately after production can these be faithfully improved. The results of this study will be used for training 2 PhD students and for engaging undergraduate students in STEM disciplines. The results will also be disseminated to a wide audience through the utilization of the research material for educational outreach efforts, including visualizations.

The project provides an unprecedented view of droplet dynamics in the turbulent wave boundary layer. Virtually all field observations of spray production rates infer fluxes based on fixed-height concentrations, and this process requires making assumptions regarding the turbulent transport of droplets in the lowest regions of the marine boundary layer. For small droplets, many of these assumptions hold, but for large droplets - those with the largest potential for altering air-sea heat and momentum fluxes - factors such as droplet inertia, flow separation behind breaking waves, and preferred wave-relative ejection locations likely violate assumptions. The research plan is aimed at several specific objectives: (i) performing controlled laboratory experiments which inform numerical simulations, and making one-to-one comparisons of statistics and bulk balances; (ii) directly compute size-resolved vertical fluxes of droplets in both experiments and simulations, in order to reveal the influence of inhomogeneous and intermittent turbulence in the vicinity of surface waves; and (iii) determine the production/deposition velocity of droplets and expand to realistic conditions using the large eddy simulations. The key outcomes will include modified flux-profile relationships of droplets of varying size, and better-informed estimates of spray-induced fluxes of heat, momentum, and moisture.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The exchanges of heat, moisture, momentum, and trace gas at the air-sea interface are extremely important for governing Earth’s climate and weather. The processes underlying this exchange occur across a huge range of spatial and temporal scales. At the very smallest end of this spectrum, the details of individual breaking waves, as well as the behavior of the numerous spray droplets that are produced in this process, combine in a complex way which ultimately dictate the bulk air-sea transfer rates of the entire ocean. For example, droplets lofted into the air (and likewise bubbles submerged in the water) can enhance the efficiency by which constituents cross the air-water interface; however, understanding this behavior is quite difficult given the huge uncertainties surrounding the number of droplets produced, how large they are, and how long they stay suspended before falling back into the ocean. Estimates of the amount of suspended spray droplets vary over multiple orders of magnitude, especially at high winds, and estimates of droplet lifetimes are equally uncertain. This project aimed at better quantifying these small-scale details, so that their collective behavior would be less uncertain, and large-scale models of air-sea interaction would be more accurate. 

 

This project was a collaborative effort between an experimental laboratory at the University of Delaware (UD), and our group at Notre Dame (ND). At ND, our primary tool for studying this problem was to use numerical simulations which can represent wind blowing over waves, while simultaneously tracking the airborne trajectory of droplets of various sizes. This simulation representation makes a lot of simplifications relative to the real experiments and the real oceans, but it provides a framework where we can track important details, such as how long each droplet remains in the air, and how much heat and moisture it exchanges while suspended. In this regard, a primary outcome of this project is this entire numerical infrastructure: the code is publicly available to download and use anywhere, so that other research communities can study other aspects of similar problems.

Our simulations were conducted to replicate conditions in the experimental facility at UD, and we generally found that they provided a faithful representation of the real system. After this verification step, we then showed that the behavior of large water droplets (those exceeding roughly 100 microns in diameter) is quite different from commonly used models. These large droplets tend to act ballistically – that is, they tend to travel like cannon balls rather than pieces of light chaff – and as a result their lifetimes are quite different than what is typically assumed. These large droplets also carry much more heat and mass than their smaller counterparts. Furthermore, the shape of the waves plays a role in how long they live, and this is somewhat intuitive: droplets which are ejected from the crests of waves live much longer than ones generated in the trough (for example from bubbles bursting). This puts a strong emphasis on needing to know exactly where droplets are being produced, and what direction they are initially traveling in, to better understand how they collectively act to modify air-sea transfer. 

This project supported the training of four undergraduate researchers and one graduate student, and has advanced both our numerical approximation of these complex problems, as well as our scientific understanding. It also facilitated outreach events, in the form of a science fair and programming club for a local K-12 school.
